Abdul Hakim's Tribute Page

⸭ Prof. Neils Bohr ⸭

"Opposites are complementary"

Here's a non-exhaustive timeline of Prof. Bohr's incredible life:

  • 1885 - Born in Copenhagen, Denmark
  • 1903 - Enrolled as an undergraduate student at Copenhagen University to study a physics major
  • 1905 - Won a gold medal at a competition to investigate a method for measuring the surface tension of liquids as proposed by Lord Rayleigh
  • 1910 - Earned his Master's degree for his work on electron theory of metals
  • 1911 - Travelled to England where he met Prof. J.J. Thomson and Prof. Earnest Rutherford
  • 1912 - Married Ms. Margrethe Nørlund and became a privatdocent
  • 1913 - Became a docent and published "the trilogy" which introduced Bohr's model of the atom
  • 1920 - Founded the Institute of Theoretical Physics at the University of Copenhagen
  • 1922 - Awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics for "for his services in the investigation of the structure of atoms and of the radiation emanating from them"
  • 1924 - Contributed to proposing the Bohr-Kramers-Slater Theory (BKS theory)
  • 1927 - Conceived the philosophical principle of complementarity and demonstrated that the uncertainty principle could be derived from classical arguments, without quantum terminology or matrices.
  • 1931 - Moved to the Carlsberg breweries mansion
  • 1939 - Elected President of the Royal Danish Academy of Sciences and Letters
  • 1941 - Famously met Prof. Heisenberg
  • 1943 - Fled to Sweden to escape the Nazis and convinced the King to provide asylum to over 7,000 Danish Jews before meeting with Tube Alloys in the UK and the Manhattan Project in the US
  • 1944 - Met with UK Prime Minister Winston Churchill and US President Franklin D. Roosevelt to discuss nuclear weapons development
  • 1945 - Returned to Copenhagen after the war
  • 1947 - Conferred the Danish Order of the Elephant
  • 1950 - Addressed an "Open Letter" to the United Nations calling for international cooperation on nuclear energy
  • 1952 - Pledged his support to CERN being constructed in Geneva
  • 1956 - Became chariman of the Research Establishment Risø of the Danish Atomic Energy Commission
  • 1957 - Received the first ever Atoms for Peace Award and became chairman of the Nordic Institute of Theoretical Physics
  • 1962 - Died of a heart failure at his home in Carlsberg
  • 1965 - The Institute of Theoretical Physics officially renamed to the Niels Bohr Institute

"Not often in life has a human being caused me such joy by his mere presence as you did."

~ Prof. Albert Einstein in a letter to Prof. Bohr
